items.title: Temporal abstraction is a key missing ingredient for long-term RL (to avoid the curse of the one-ste...
items.content:
Temporal abstraction is a key missing ingredient for long-term RL (to avoid the curse of the one-step model, as @RichardSSutton likes to say). Language is one approach to such abstraction, but animals show it can be learned from data without human labels. But how? It is hard to learn learn temporally abstract options using standard hierarchical RL methods. This paper, from the Google team led by @neurosacramento,  takes an approach inspired by LLM pre and post training. Let me explain.

First it pre-trains a sequence model on unlabeled expert trajectories, generated by goal-seeking agents. The model learns to predict the next action (and optionally next observation) given previous observations, without knowing the goal or the sequence boundaries. The model is a standard transformer, with L blocks, shown in Fig 1. Here e(t,l) is the residual stream at time t and layer l. These learn the relevant temporal abstractions.

Next it modifies the model by inserting a control signal, U(t), at layer l, to get e'(t,l)=e(t,l) + U(t) e(t,l). This generates the desired action a'(t), as shown in Fig 2. The control signal is generated from a latent variable, u(t) = f(z(t)). This model  is trained (using amoritzed variational inference) to maximize the likelihood of another set of expert trajectories, using a non-causal encoder, z(t)=enc(o(1:T)). 

Finally, it replaces the offline variational controller with a causal controller, that is trained using online RL (with the rest of the model being frozen). At each step, the SSM-based controller generates a stochastic latent z'(t). In addition, a GRU-based switching module generates a switch probability, beta(t).  Finally the latent control z(t) is either set to the new latent action z'(t), or it remains equal to the previous latent action, z(t-1), as determined by a (thresholded) beta(t). See fig 3. This generates long chunks of constant action signals, corresponding to temporally abstract options.

The result is a method that can learn to control a low-level mujoco ant (given full observability) to solve long horizon tasks, visiting combinatorially new sequences of goal locations.

The authors also claim this model is similar to the how the brain solves such problems - the  transformer model is like the cortex (designed to predict what will happen next in the environment given that the agent is following some goal), and the controller is like the basal ganglia / striatum, designed to choose the next latent internal goal to aim for.

items.title: One very familiar pattern in AI and science right now is going from a lot of false starts on hard ta...
items.content:
One very familiar pattern in AI and science right now is going from a lot of false starts on hard tasks (there have been near-misses where AI appears to solve an Erdos problem but just finds an old solution no one knew about) to actually doing the thing soon after.

Three Erdos problems in 3 days.

items.title: Large language models store factual knowledge in their parameters, and sometimes that knowledge is w...
items.content:
Large language models store factual knowledge in their parameters, and sometimes that knowledge is wrong or outdated. **Model editing** refers to techniques that modify specific facts in a trained model without expensive retraining‚Äîfor example, updating "The President of the United States is X" to reflect a new president.

Existing methods work by finding which parameters encode a fact (by using a technique called **causal tracing**) and then adding a small change to those parameters. This approach, however, creates a new problem: Changes that successfully insert new information corrupt the model's existing knowledge, and when you perform many edits in sequence, the model eventually starts producing repetitive gibberish.

AlphaEdit described in this ICLR 2025 Outstanding Paper offers a mathematically clean way around this trade-off. The authors report an average 36.7% improvement across their experiments, with models maintaining coherent text generation even after thousands of sequential edits.

Active reading on ChapterPal: https://t.co/UHKL4bAHqG

PDF: https://t.co/tuFGEwu3an

items.title: I think that at this point, given that LLMs are heavily finetuned using reinforcement learning to in...
items.content:
I think that at this point, given that LLMs are heavily finetuned using reinforcement learning to interact with the larger vibe coding system, if you manually fix the code generated by an LLM to resemble your understanding of good code, you make it harder for the vibe coding system to work with your code.

I think that removing the constraint of human readability from code would make the vibe coding system more capable.

items.content:
If you‚Äôre building a mega technical product, you should probably do it in a way that people don‚Äôt need to appreciate the tech to enjoy the product.

Otherwise, if you require your buyer to be super sophisticated, they might just want to build the thing themselves anyway.

items.title: @HanchungLee I didn't say that it is always wrong to saturate your tests. Of course you're going to ...
items.author: @HamelHusain
items.summary: Hamel Husain discusses test saturation in AI evaluation - warns against complacency when tests pass, advocates for continually adding unmet test cases
items.reasoning: Practical LLM evaluation advice from respected ML practitioner. Important for prompt engineering and AI system testing
items.summary_html: Hamel Husain discusses test saturation in AI evaluation - warns against complacency when tests pass, advocates for continually adding unmet test cases
items.content_html:
@HanchungLee I didn't say that it is always wrong to saturate your tests. Of course you're going to saturate your tests but you should always view saturation with a high level of skepticism and think "can you add test cases that you haven't passed yet".

It is a flash card after all so have to strike a balance between guidance and capturing all the exceptions!

The point of the Flashcard is to help people avoid this trap which stems from lack of data thinking https://t.co/xass5GxJg5

items.title: I asked Grok which country has the largest contiguous north-south extent. Attached map was added by ...
items.content:
I asked Grok which country has the largest contiguous north-south extent. Attached map was added by me. Here is Grok‚Äôs interesting response:

**The country with the largest north-south extent** is a surprisingly debated topic, but based on reliable measurements of **contiguous (continuous) mainland territory**, **Brazil** edges out **Chile** by a small margin.

### Key Comparisons
- **Brazil**:  
  - North-south distance ‚âà **4,378‚Äì4,395 km**  
  - Latitude span ‚âà **39 degrees** (roughly from 5.27¬∞N to 33.75¬∞S)  
  - This makes it the longest continuous north-south span among sovereign countries.

- **Chile**:  
  - North-south distance ‚âà **4,270‚Äì4,300 km** (sometimes cited as 4,620 km in older/rounded sources)  
  - Latitude span ‚âà **38‚Äì39 degrees** (roughly from 17.5¬∞S to 56¬∞S, or 55.98¬∞S when precise)  
  - Famous for its narrow, elongated shape ‚Äî often popularly called the "longest" country.

The CIA World Factbook and many general sources still describe **Chile** as the longest north-south trending country, likely due to historical rounding of latitude extremes (e.g., rounding to 17¬∞S‚Äì56¬∞S). However, more precise geographic calculations (from sources like Reddit geography discussions citing exact coordinates, Quora analyses, and direct distance measurements) consistently show **Brazil** slightly ahead for contiguous land.

### Other Notable Contenders
- **Russia** ‚Üí North-south extent is only ~2,500‚Äì4,000 km (latitude ~41¬∞N to 82¬∞N), but it is overwhelmingly east-west oriented.
- Countries with discontinuous territories (e.g., France or Norway including overseas departments/territories) can claim much larger spans but are usually excluded from "contiguous" rankings.

**Bottom line**: If we're talking about the greatest uninterrupted north-south distance across continuous territory, **Brazil** holds the title ‚Äî though **Chile** remains the most iconic and widely recognized "tall" country due to its dramatic shape and near-universal mention in textbooks and media.

items.title:
This one isn't airfryer but 100% oven

This is my famous üçã Acid Chicken recipe: get local butcher ch...
items.content:
This one isn't airfryer but 100% oven

This is my famous üçã Acid Chicken recipe: get local butcher chicken legs then add squeezed lemon, Kikkoman soy sauce, put a lot, then marinate with skin down for a few hours or overnight

Then take out and flip chicken, add smoked paprika powder, some rosemary or other spices you like

Then about 25-30min in a preheated fan oven at 220C/430F

At same time you can put frozen brussel sprouts and other veg in, add salt and pepper

Prep time I'd say 5mins

Add rice if you want some carbs and try out the juice on the rice it's great

Very tasty and very healthy! üòã

items.title:
My current AI stack (ranked in usage):
1. GPT 5.2 Thinking/Pro: Primary driver, search, information,...
items.content:
My current AI stack (ranked in usage):
1. GPT 5.2 Thinking/Pro: Primary driver, search, information, synthesis, planning.
2. Claude Opus 4.5: Feedback, basic debugging, data viz
3. Gemini 3: Multimodal, queries
4. Grok 4: X search

This has changed a lot from last summer, where I was almost exclusively using GPT 5 Thinking (previously o3). Diversity points to a more exciting ecosystem.

If you want to feel the frontier of AI you need to be using multiple models for their best strengths and learning to hand off in between them.

In my latest post, I explain what this means about the models and how they're evolving (the jagged frontier).

items.content_html:
My current AI stack (ranked in usage):

1. GPT 5.2 Thinking/Pro: Primary driver, search, information, synthesis, planning.

2. Claude Opus 4.5: Feedback, basic debugging, data viz

3. Gemini 3: Multimodal, queries

4. Grok 4: X search

This has changed a lot from last summer, where I was almost exclusively using GPT 5 Thinking (previously o3). Diversity points to a more exciting ecosystem.

If you want to feel the frontier of AI you need to be using multiple models for their best strengths and learning to hand off in between them.

In my latest post, I explain what this means about the models and how they're evolving (the jagged frontier).

items.title: @OmnipotentCEO @latimes Jobs create tax revenue, which gives liberals the money to do social things‚Äî...
items.content:
@OmnipotentCEO @latimes Jobs create tax revenue, which gives liberals the money to do social things‚Äîwhich I'm usually in support of‚Äîbut if you chase away the money, you're going to chase away the innovation engine that created Silicon Valley and so much wealth for California.

The Los Angeles Times is just on the wrong side of this one. We all need to be on the side of jobs. Jobs are number one; everything else comes after you get jobs. If you have no jobs, you have no tax revenue (and no ability to do good for people).

items.title:
We buy like 5 loafs from the local bakery every few months

Then cut all loaf in slices, I got this ...
items.content:
We buy like 5 loafs from the local bakery every few months

Then cut all loaf in slices, I got this bread cutting machine for it on Amazon

Then we freeze those slices

We don't eat bread a lot but sometimes, so if you wanna eat bread, you just put a frozen slice in air fryer for about 7 minutes and you have toasted bread

One reason is that whenever we go to the bakery here after 12 noon all bread is sold out, so this is easier

Now studies show freezing bread and other starches is healthier for you as it doesn't spike your blood sugar as much

Related I try to start my day with protein, never carbs or sugar, just egg or meat and then carbs or fruit after

I know lots of people start their day with fruits cause I see it at hotel breakfast and I try avoid starting my day with that

This trick originally from @AndreyAzimov who got it from Michael from @dojobali

items.content:
@AMIRREZA1ASADI It's very depressing to watch. I'm an American married to an Iranian, and we're just holding our breath, hoping that this protest succeeds this time. We hope the government doesn't learn that it can just use violence against its own citizens to keep this uprising down. 

But this is all on the Iranian people now: either they're tired of this, or they're going to have to live with years and years more of it.
